titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the John E. Fleming Papers, 1962-2013 RL.11014
titlestmt.author: Meghan Lyon

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2018-01-23 16:04:38 -0500.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Dr. John E. Fleming served as director of the National Afro-American Museum and Cultural Center in Wilberforce, Ohio, from 1988-1998 and served on numerous boards and committees to develop and plan museums and exhibits focused on African American history. His papers reflect his career as a historian of African American history and as a museum administrator in museums throughout the United States. Collection acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center.
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The collection includes Fleming's personal files, administrative materials, and collected documents from his education and professional life as a professor and museum administrator. Files have been arranged into series: Writings, Organizational Files, Museum Leadership, Printed Materials and Research, Asa Spaulding Project, Education, Personal, and Correspondence. The bulk of the collection is held in the Organizational Files and Museum Leadership series.

The Organizational Files Series contains a large subseries of Fleming's Consulting Work, as well as files from Fleming's membership and service to groups like ASALH, AAAM, Sigma Pi Phi, and other civic or professional organizations. This series also includes Fleming's board work with Berea College, the Ohio Humanities Council, the American Civil War Center, and other historically-minded groups.

The Museum Leadership Series is arranged by museum; Fleming served as director or in some executive capacity with each of the museums in this series. Most subseries include his correspondence, planning and design materials, exhibition materials, and other documents accounting for the early operations of the museums. Also included in this series are materials from the America I Am exhibit, which Fleming produced. Two of the subseries are restricted: the International African American Museum subseries is closed until 2018, and the Mississippi Civil Rights Museum is closed until 2017.

The rest of the collection's series are relatively smaller, in terms of volume. The Writings Series includes Fleming's speeches and publications; files are arranged by format and then alphabetically by title. Printed Materials and Research include his clippings, articles, and publications he kept as reference materials for his museum work and academic research. The Asa Spaulding Project includes oral history notes, transcripts, and cassette tapes from Fleming's work as a research assistant for Spaulding's autobiography. The Education Series includes coursework and notes from his own college and graduate courses, as well as files from his teaching at Howard University following his graduation. The Personal Series contains an assortment of materials, including job searches, clippings about him and his family, and other ephemera. Finally, Fleming's Correspondence Series includes both personal and professional communications, which are arranged in a loose chronological order by year.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by: Meghan Lyon, Janice Hansen, and Zoe Willingham, April 2015 Accessions described in this finding aid: 2013-0107

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], John E. Fleming Papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The John Fleming Papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 2013.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: John E. Fleming (1944- ) is originally from Morganton, N.C., and graduated from Berea College in 1966. He served for two years in the Peace Corps in Malawi, and then attended Howard University, earning a Ph.D. in History. In the 1970s, he worked with Howard's Institute for the Study of Educational Policy and also as a professor in the History Dept. Fleming was the founding director of the National Afro-American Museum and Cultural Center in Cincinnati, and also served as director of the National Underground Railroad Freedom Center in Wilberforce, Ohio. Fleming later worked as Vice President of Museums at the Cincinnal Museum Center; served as the executive producer for Tavis Smiley's America I Am: The African American Imprint exhibit, which toured nationwide; and was director or consultant for several other museums and historic sites, including the International African American Museum, the Mississippi Civil Rights Museum, and the National African American Museum. Fleming has authored several books on African American history and education, and has also published a novel, A Summer Remembered. He is a past president of the Association for the Study of African American Life and History, the Ohio Museums Association, and the Association of African American Museums.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes drafts and published versions of Fleming's speeches, journal articles, essays, and books. Speeches range from personal tributes to academic lectures, and are arranged alphabetically by title. Dates and any additional information are included when known. Fleming's Academic Writings include his dissertation and subsequent versions of his research on Burke County, N.C., as well as research and articles on affirmative action, African American culture and history, and museum leadership. The Fiction Writings contains drafts of A Summer Remembered, a partly-autobiographical novel published by Fleming.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fleming's wide range of service on various boards, professional organizations, and commissions are documented in this series. The Consulting subseries includes assorted projects and early employment records, as well as ephemera from his Peace Corps Service. The rest of the subseries represent specific groups Fleming worked with between the 1980s and the 2010s.

did.unittitle: Consulting, Early Professional Work, Professional Affiliations, and Community Service

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes Fleming's work as a consultant for various African American history museums or organizations, as well as his membership and service in various community, fraternal, and professional groups. Materials are arranged alphabetically by organization, group, or project. Of note in this subseries are files related to Fleming's early professional career, including the Peace Corps, Afro-American Bicentennial Corporation, and Youth Pride, Inc., as well as files documenting his participation in groups like Sigma Phi Pi, Leadership Cincinnati, and Alpha Phi Alpha.

did.unittitle: Institute for the Study of Educational Policy, Howard University

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fleming was a Senior Fellow at the Institute for the Study of Educational Policy from 1974 to 1980. This subseries is divided into two parts: Fleming's subject files, collected during his time at ISEP, and then general files from his work at ISEP. Many of the materials focus on the impact and viability of affirmative action in higher education. Another notable project Fleming worked on during this period was the E Pluribus Unum project with Miami Dade Communite College, which sought to develop a new curriculum or textbook for the teaching of American history. Additional materials from Fleming's work at ISEP can be found in the Writings Series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fleming was president of ASALH from 2007 to 2009. This subseries includes materials from his membership and leadership, including annual meeting materials; executive council and board materials; Black History Month promotions, fundraising, and programming; and other files relating to his ASALH service.

Financial statements and independent auditor's report
Brown and the Ordeal of Integrationism in Black Identity

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Programs, notes, and other materials from Fleming's attendance at ASALH's annual meetings, sometimes called conventions. Years included are 1975-1977, 1980, 1982, 1983, 1989, 1991, 1996, 2004, 2005, 2007-2012. The file for the 1983 annual meeting includes a program with Rosa Parks' autograph.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains materials from Fleming's service and support of the Berea College (Kentucky) Board of Trustees, including board meetings, Berea publications, trustee administrative files, and committee work. Also includes a file on Fleming's establishment of the Ward/Ivory endowment at Berea.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The BOT met three times per year, in February, May, and October. These files include meeting packets prepared for each BOT member as well as Fleming's accompanying correspondence and some notes from his attendance at the meetings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Appointment and meeting materials from Fleming's service on the Ohio Humanities Council.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The OHC met four times per year: March, June, October, and December. These files contain Fleming's meeting packets, correspondence, as well as grant applications and other materials he reviewed on behalf of the OHC.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fleming's materials collected from his role as a board member for Richmond's Historic Tredegar, including meeting materials, collections and management policies, events, and press. Materials document the evolution of Historic Tredegar and its eventual renovation and reopening as the American Civil War Center at Historic Tredegar.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The BOT usually met three times per year. These files include meeting packets prepared for each BOT member as well as clippings, Fleming's accompanying correspondence, and some notes from his attendance at the meetings.

did.unittitle: National Afro-American Museum and Cultural Center/Ohio Historical Society

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains Fleming's materials from his time as Project Director for the Ohio Historical Society (1980-1988) and subsequently materials from his role as Director of the National Afro-American Museum and Cultural Center in Wilberforce, Ohio (1988-1998). Includes both OHS personnel and administrative documents, as well as materials from the planning and construction the museum.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains materials from the planning, design, and construction of the National Underground Railroad Freedom Center, where Fleming served as director from 1998 to 2000. Includes internal discussions, reports, and correspondence about the anticipated mission and scope of the NURFC, as well as feasability studies, publicity campaigns, and press coverage.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains extensive notes, correspondence, and internal documentation from the planning process for Tavis Smiley's America I Am: African American Imprint on America, a 12,000 square foot traveling exhibition; Fleming served as Executive Producer of the project. The exhibit opened in Philadelphia in 2009 and toured throughout the country until 2011.

scopecontent.p: Includes materials from the planning and design of the International African American Museum in Charleston, SC, scheduled to open in 2017. Fleming served as advisor and part-time director.

scopecontent.p: Materials from Fleming's work with the Mississippi Civil Rights Museum, including project designs, surveys, and grant applications. Fleming was hired by Hilferty and Associates, the design firm responsible for the MCRM. The MCRM's anticipated opening is 2017.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fleming's Printed Materials and Research contain his subject files on various topics, largely related to affirmative action, African American history, and museum operations -- including planning and design of exhibits, educational programs, curation, finances, and leadership. Formats range from printed publications to newspaper clippings. Some materials include Fleming's annotations.

did.unittitle: Book reviews collected by J. Fleming

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists largely of Fleming's notes and interview transcripts from his work as a research assistant for Asa Spaulding, who intended to write an autobiography in the early 1980s. Fleming conducted oral history interviews with many of Spaulding's acquaintances and colleagues in support of the project, and also researched Spaulding's personal history. Some audiotapes of interviews are available for research. Transcripts and notes are arranged alphabetically by interviewee.

did.unittitle: Kennedy, W.J., Jr., and Meg Kennedy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Education Series includes files from Fleming's college and graduate work at Berea College and Howard University, as well as his teaching and departmental materials from his work as a professor in Howard University's History Dept. Fleming's dissertation drafts are available in the Writings Series.

African American history course materials and notes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Personal Series includes an assortment of files, including some of Fleming's job applications as well as various calendars and datebooks, resumes and biographies, clippings about him and his family, and other ephemera that he collected and saved.

did.unittitle: Funeral arrangements and other details for James E. Fleming
University of Maryland Driskell Center application
Oral history interview re: Berea College and March to Selma

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The majority of this series consists of Fleming's correspondence, both personal and professional, which has been loosely arranged by year. Three files at the end of the series are segregated by subject, representing how they were originally donated to the Rubenstein: Fleming's correspondence with Berea College; Fleming's correspondence with Mary Ann Olding over her dissertation process; and Fleming's correspondence about the Selective Service and his status as a Conscientious Objector during the Vietnam War.
